newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Blast kills three in centre of Chechen capital.
newsitem.headline: Blast kills three in centre of Chechen capital.

text.p: At least three people died on Wednesday when their vehicle exploded in the centre of Grozny, capital of Russia's breakaway Chechnya region.

A Reuters correspondent saw the charred bodies of three men inside a minibus which had been ripped open and overturned by a powerful explosion near the headquarters of a hardline guerrilla leader. A woman passerby was also wounded.
Police were investigating and declined to comment.

The car, with registration plates of neighbouring Dagestan, was parked close to the headquarters of Salman Raduyev, a hardline rebel fighter who has refused to recognise a peace deal struck last August between Russia and Chechnya.
Witnesses said Raduyev had left the building about fifteen minutes before the explosion.

The unruly Chechen guerilla commander raided the neighbouring ethnic republic of Dagestan in January 1996, held hundreds of hostages there and later escaped safely though the lines of Russian commandos.
Raduyev has survived a number of assasination attempts.
Tens of thousands of people were killed in a 21-month war between local separatists and Russian troops which ended in August with agreement on a Russian withdrawal.
